awd_titl_txt: HDR TRIPODS: Penn Institute for Foundations of Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The growing field of data science promises to bring many benefits to society: personalized knowledge and services; improved healthcare; improved decision-making at individual, organizational, national, and international levels; a safer and possibly fairer society; and many others. The ability to realize these promises, however, depends critically on building the right foundational principles for the field. This project establishes an NSF TRIPODS Institute, termed the Penn Institute for Foundations of Data Science (PIFODS), at the University of Pennsylvania, with the goal of bringing together scientists and ideas from multiple disciplines, including computer science, electrical engineering, statistics, and mathematics, in order to collectively develop long-lasting principles for data science that can serve the field for decades to come. The main activities of the Institute will include transdisciplinary research, education and training, engagement with the broader research community through invited seminars and workshops, and engagement with applied scientists and practitioners. 

The PIFODS team seeks to develop principles for the following five thrusts: principles for complex learning tasks; principles for efficient optimization (convex, non-convex, and submodular); principles for streaming, distributed, and massively parallel data analysis; principles for privacy-preserving and fairness-preserving data analysis; and principles for reproducible data analysis. Each of these thrusts addresses an important foundational need in data science. These needs range from designing learning algorithms with stronger performance guarantees, and developing principles for optimization in adaptive settings, to developing a fundamental understanding of the tradeoffs between various modern computational resources in data science, as well as developing data science algorithms that guarantee meaningful notions of privacy, fairness, and reproducibility. Each thrust requires interactions among several of the TRIPODS disciplines; several of these thrusts also naturally interact with each other. On the education and training side, the PIFODS team has already initiated several new transdisciplinary courses related to data science that are aimed at developing a common language across disciplines; under the aegis of the Institute, the team will continue to further develop and refine these courses, and will incorporate feedback from these courses to inform the university's emerging transdisciplinary data science curriculum. On the applications side, the PIFODS team will actively engage with applied scientists and practitioners of data science, including both members of the broader university community and selected industry practitioners; these engagements will both help to inform possible additional research thrusts in the future, and help to solve important data-driven problems in society. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The HDR TRIPODS: Penn Institute for Foundations of Data Science aimed to establish fundamental principles that will underpin data science for decades to come. By bringing together researchers across computer science, statistics, mathematics, and electrical engineering, the Institute pursued five critical research areas: complex learning tasks; efficient optimization; streaming, distributed, and massively parallel data analysis; privacy and fairness; and reproducibility in data analysis.

Over the course of this project, significant intellectual advances were made. In machine learning, the team developed robust methods for learning with noisy or adversarially corrupted data and advanced theories of multiclass classification, including clarifying distinctions between different consistency notions crucial for practical algorithms. Major breakthroughs included efficient algorithms for submodular optimization, fundamental understanding of adversarial robustness in statistical models, and techniques enabling fairness and calibration across diverse populations, addressing biases and ensuring equitable outcomes.

The team made significant strides in uncertainty quantification, developing new methods to improve predictions' reliability. Notably, advances in conformal prediction enabled the creation of prediction intervals valid for finely defined demographic subgroups and robust against adversarial data manipulations. These methods have practical implications in fields ranging from healthcare to autonomous systems.

Optimization research included efficient, sublinear-space algorithms essential for processing massive graphs and data streams, significant in fields like social network analysis and computational biology. The team also addressed longstanding open problems in discrete optimization, providing foundational insights into submodular function minimization and hierarchical clustering.

In addition to research, the institute significantly impacted education and training, providing interdisciplinary education to numerous PhD students and postdoctoral researchers. Graduates moved into influential academic and industry positions, reinforcing the institute's role as a training ground for future leaders in data science.

Broader impacts included active engagement with the broader community through public lectures, popular media articles, and policy engagements. Highlights included the widely disseminated book, "The Ethical Algorithm," raising public awareness on ethical implications of algorithmic decision-making. Institute researchers regularly engaged with industry and policymakers to translate theoretical findings into practical applications, enhancing privacy practices and fairness in real-world systems.

Overall, the TRIPODS project has substantially advanced foundational data science, produced new methods for fair and robust machine learning, improved uncertainty quantification, and developed efficient computational techniques essential for big data analytics, thereby establishing enduring principles that will guide data science research and practice for years to come.
